title: Regarding the Bible why does it say ' I will sweep her with a broom of annihilation!' But King Cyrus didn't destroy Babylon, in fact Babylon was still there until after Alexander could this have been a type-o or a miss quote? - Quora

response.answer_text: The demise of Babylon took centuries. One fact, the empire that was the Babylonian, ceased to exist, and the city itself became a subjected city under many empires that followed. Gradually it’s importance as part of a trade route died out. Today, the city is a collection of ruins, dug out of the sands of time. While there may be a community living there, it is not a grand city of an empire, just a ghost of its former self. Most that live there are involved in the research of history or providing tourists with information. Look at the pictures attached in the Wikipedia article on Babylon.[1] It has truly been “Swept” by a broom of annihilation. Footnotes[1] Babylon - Wikipedia

Often in. I let prophecy Babylon is used as a metaphor for sin. Babylon was a sinful city and during. iblical times was one of the biggest cities and had lots of enemies and conquered a lot of other cities, they had a huge reputation. God used them as a metaphor in prophesies….anyone or any group/country that is like Babylon is going to be destroyed by God….he considers them to be Babylon metaphorically.

Babylon was both a city and an empire. In 539 BC, Cyrus did conquer the Neo-Babylonian Empire, making it a part of his ever growing Persian Empire. The land and the city remained for Alexander to annihilate.
